• “Hocus Pocus 2” (PG): Sequel to the Halloween classic which brings back the wicked Sanderson sisters for more comedic mayhem. Starring Bette Midler, Sarah Jessica Parker and Kathy Najimy. Available on Disney+.

• “Jeepers Creepers Reborn” (R): Fourth film in the “Jeepers Creepers” franchise. Starring Sydney Craven, Jarreau Benjamin, Timo Vuorensola and Imran Adams.

• “Thor-Love and Thunder” (PG-13): Marvel Studios’ film where Thor (Chris Hemsworth) is on a journey to find inner peace. But his retirement is interrupted by a galactic killer known as Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks the extinction of the gods. To combat the killer, Thor enlists the help of King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Korg (Taika Waititi) and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman).

• “Dragon Ball Super-Super Hero” (PG-13): New film in the Dragon Ball anime series. The Red Ribbon Army was once destroTOP-L-Movies-LIST-0930yed by Son Goku. Individuals who carry on its spirit have created the ultimate androids: Gamma 1 and Gamma 2.

• “Bullet Train” (R): Five assassins on a fast moving bullet train from Tokyo to Morioka discover their missions are connected but have conflicting goals. Starring Brad Pitt, Bad Bunny, Sandra Bullock and Joey King.

• “Vengeance” (R): Dark comic thriller starring and directed by B.J. Novak, about a journalist and podcaster who travels from New York City to West Texas to investigate the death of a woman whom he hooked up with. Also starring Issa Rae and Ashton Kutcher.

• “Orphan: First Kill” (R): After escaping from a psychiatric facility in Estonia, Esther travels to America by impersonating the missing daughter of a wealthy family. Prequel to “Orphan”, starring Isabelle Fuhrman, Julia Stiles and Matthew Finlan.

• “Elvis” (PG-13): Biopic film about the life and music of Elvis Presley (Austin Butler), focusing on his complicated relationship with his enigmatic manager, Colonel Tom Parker (Tom Hanks), spanning over 20 years. Also starring Olivia DeJonge as Priscilla Presley.

• “Entergalactic”: Adult animated film about a young artist named Jabari (musician Scott “Kid Cudi” Mescudi) who moves into his dream apartment in New York and falls for his new neighbor, photographer it-girl, Meadow (Jessica Williams). Available on Netflix.

• “God’s Country” (R): A college professor confronts two hunters trespassing on her property in the mountains. The film is based on the short story “Winter Light” by James Lee Burke. Starring Thandiwe Newton, Jefferson White, Tanaya Beatty and Jeremy Bobb.

• “Breaking” (PG-13): Desperate for money, a Marine veteran holds several people hostage inside a bank, causing a tense confrontation with police. Starring John Boyega, Michael Kenneth Williams, Nicole Beharie and Connie Britton.

• “Nope” (R): Science fiction horror film written, directed, and co-produced by Jordan Peele about caretakers at a California horse ranch who encounter a mysterious force. Starring Daniel Kaluuya, Keke Palmer and Steven Yeun.

• “Bodies Bodies Bodies” (R): A group of rich 20-somethings attend a hurricane party at a remote family mansion where a party game goes awry. Starring Amandla Stenberg, Maria Bakalova and Rachel Sennott.

• “After Ever Happy” (R): The fourth film in the “After” romantic drama series, based on the 2015 novel of the same name by Anna Todd. Starring Hero Fiennes Tiffin, Josephine Langford and Carter Jenkins.

• “Medieval“ (R): A Czech historical drama film based on Bohemian military commander Jan Zizka, who was one of the greatest warriors in history. Starring Ben Foster, Matthew Goode and Sophie Lowe.

• “Blonde” (NC-17): Based on the bestselling novel by Joyce Carol Oates, about the life of Marilyn Monroe. Starring Ana de Armas, Bobby Cannavale and Adrien Brody. Available on Netflix.

• “Mack & Rita” (PG-13): When 30-year-old Mack Martin reluctantly joins a Palm Springs, Calif., bachelorette trip for her best friend Carla, her inner 70-year-old gets released — literally. The frustrated writer and influencer magically transforms into her future self: aunt Rita. Starring Diane Keaton, Elizabeth Lail, Wendie Malick and Dustin Milligan.

• “The Black Phone” (R): Finney Shaw, a shy 13-year-old boy, is abducted by a sadistic killer and trapped in a soundproof basement. When a disconnected phone on the wall begins to ring, Finney discovers that he can hear the voices of the killer’s previous victims. Starring Mason Thames, Madeleine McGraw, Jeremy Davies, James Ransom and Ethan Hawke.

• “Beast” (R): Thriller about a father and his two teenage daughters who find themselves hunted by a massive rogue lion. Starring Idris Elba, Leah Jeffries, Iyana Halley and Sharlto Copley.

• “Running the Bases” (PG): A small-town baseball coach takes a job at a larger high school, and moves his family to the larger school’s town. As a man of faith, he soon faces opposition to his coaching methods from the superintendent. Starring Brett Varvel, Gigi Orsillo, Brad Stine and Cameron Arnett.

• “Andor”: Disney+ series shows a new perspective from the “Star Wars” galaxy, focusing on Cassian Andor, bringing forward the tale of the burgeoning rebellion against the Empire. Starring Diego Luna, Genevieve O’Reilly, Stellan Skarsgård and Adria Arjona. Available on Disney+.

• “Sidney” (PG-13): Documentary from producer Oprah Winfrey, honoring the legendary Sidney Poitier-iconic actor, filmmaker, and civil rights activist. It features interviews with Denzel Washington, Spike Lee, Barbra Streisand, Robert Redford and more. Available on Apple TV+.

• “Honk for Jesus. Save Your Soul” (R): Comedy satire about the first lady and pastor of a Southern Baptist megachurch. After a scandal forces their church to temporarily close, they must rebuild their congregation. Starring Regina Hall, Sterling K. Brown, Austin Crute, Nicole Beharie and Selah Kimbra Jones.

• “Sago Mini Friends”: Animated series focused on gratitude, with Havey the floppy-eared dog and his best friends, Jinja the cat, Jack the rabbit, and Robin the bird. Based on Sago Mini World app. Available on Apple TV+.

• “End of the Road” (R): Thriller about a cross-country road trip where a mother and her two children and her brother witness a brutal murder and find themselves in the crosshairs of a mysterious killer. Starring Queen Latifah, Chris Bridges and Mychala Faith Lee with Beau Bridges. Available on Netflix.

• “The Lord of the Rings-The Rings of Power”: Series drama set thousands of years before the events of J.R.R. Tolkien’s “The Hobbit” and “The Lord of the Rings.” Starring Morfydd Clark, Robert Aramayo, Markella Kavenagh and Joseph Mawle. Available on Amazon Prime Video.

• “Love in the Villa”: A young woman takes a trip to Verona, Italy, after a break up, and finds the villa she reserved was double-booked, and she’ll have to share it with a British man. Starring Kat Graham, Tom Hopper, and Raymond Ablack. Available on Netflix.

• “Samaritan” (PG-13): A 13-year-old boy comes to the realization that his reclusive neighbor may be a famed superhero, who was thought to have gone missing after an epic battle twenty years ago. Starring Sylvester Stallone, Javon Walton and Martin Starr. Available on Amazon Prime Video.

• “Easter Sunday” (PG-13): Jo Koy plays a fictionalized version of himself as he attends a family gathering to celebrate Easter Sunday. Starring Jo Koy, Jimmy O. Yang and Tia Carrere.

• “Mo”: Mo Najjar struggles to adapt to a new world, straddled between two cultures and three languages as a Palestinian refugee, on the path to U.S. citizenship. His family — including his resilient and spiritual mother, sister and older brother — flee to Houston, Texas. Starring Mo Amer, Teresa Ruiz and Farah Bsieso. Available on Netflix.

• “Me Time” (R): A stay-at-home dad finds himself with some “me time” for the first time in years while his wife and children are away, and reconnects with his former best friend for a wild weekend. Starring Kevin Hart, Mark Wahlberg, Regina Hall and Jimmy O. Yang. Available on Netflix.

• “See” Season 3 (TV-MA): Series set in a primitive future, where humankind has lost the ability to see. Starring Jason Momoa, Sylvia Hoeks and Hera Hilmar. Available on Apple TV+.

• “Three Thousand Years of Longing” (R): Dr. Alithea Binnie is an academic attending a conference in Istanbul. She encounters a djinn (spirit), who offers her three wishes in exchange for his freedom. She is doubtful and knows all the cautionary tales of wishes gone wrong. The djinn pleads his case and she eventually makes a wish that surprises them both. Starring Tilda Swinton and Idris Elba.

• “Jurassic World Dominion” (PG-13): In the conclusion to the Jurassic era, two generations unite for the first time, four years after Isla Nublar has been destroyed. Dinosaurs now live-and hunt-alongside humans all over the world. This fragile balance will reshape the future and determine whether humans remain at the top of the food chain. Starring Chris Pratt, Bryce Dallas Howard, Laura Dern, Jeff Goldblum, Sam Neill.

• “Look Both Ways”: On the eve of her college graduation, Natalie’s (Lili Reinhart) life diverges into parallel realities: one in which she becomes pregnant and remains in her hometown, and another in which she does not and moves to Los Angeles. Also starring Danny Ramirez, David Corenswet and Aisha Dee, with Andrea Savage, Luke Wilson and Nia Long. Available on Netflix.

• “She-Hulk: Attorney at Law”: Marvel Studios nine-episode comedy series with Jennifer Walters (Tatiana Maslany) as an attorney specializing in superhuman-oriented legal cases. She is a single, 30-something who also happens to be a green 6-foot-7-inch superpowered hulk. Also starring Mark Ruffalo, Tim Roth, and Benedict Wong. Available on Disney+.

• “Day Shift” (R): Jamie Foxx stars as a hard-working dad who wants to provide a good life for his quick-witted daughter. His mundane San Fernando Valley pool cleaning job is a front for his real source of income, hunting and killing vampires as part of an international union of vampire hunters. Also starring Dave Franco, Steve Howey, and Scott Adkins. Available on Netflix.

• “Paws of Fury-The Legend of Hank” (PG): Animated adventure about a hound named Hank (Michael Cera) who finds himself in a town full of cats who need a hero to defend them from a ruthless villain (Ricky Gervais). With help from a reluctant teacher (Samuel L. Jackson) to train him, the underdog must assume the role of town samurai.

• “Marcel the Shell with Shoes On” (PG): Marcel is a 1-inch-tall shell who lives with his grandmother, Connie. Once part of a sprawling community of shells, they are now the sole survivors of a mysterious tragedy. Starring Jenny Slate (voice of Marcel), Dean Fleischer‑Camp, Isabella Rossellini (voice of Connie), and Rosa Salazar. Available on Amazon Prime Video.

• “Rise of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles”: New animated film in the Nickelodeon series with Raphael, Michelangelo, Leonardo and Donatello back in action and up to their teenage antics, featuring the voices of Ben Schwartz, Omar Miller, Brandon Smith and Josh Bren. Available on Netflix.

• “Lightyear” (PG): Animated sci-fi action-adventure and definitive origin story of Buzz Lightyear of “Toy Story”. Starring Chris Evans, Uzo Aduba, James Brolin and Mary McDonald-Lewis. Available on Disney+.

• “Prey” (R): Set in the Comanche Nation 300 years ago, a young woman, Naru, a fierce and highly skilled warrior, raised in the shadow of legendary hunters, sets out to protect her people from an alien predator. Starring Amber Midthunder, Dakota Beavers and Stormee Kipp. Available on Hulu.

• “Luck” (G): Animated film about Sam Greenfield (Eva Noblezada), the unluckiest person in the world who discovers the never-before-seen Land of Luck. Also starring the voices of Simon Pegg, Whoopi Goldberg, Flula Borg and Jane Fonda. Available on Apple TV+.

• “Thirteen Lives” (PG-13): Based on a true story about a rescue mission in Thailand where a group of young boys and their soccer coach became trapped in a system of underground caves that were flooding. Starring Joel Edgerton, Colin Farrell and Viggo Mortensen. Directed by Ron Howard. Available on Amazon Prime Video.

• “Not Okay” (R): Danni Sanders (Zoey Deutch), an aspiring writer with no friends, and no followers, fakes an Instagram-friendly trip to Paris in the hopes of boosting her social media clout. Also starring Dylan O’Brien, Embeth Davidtz and Brennan Brown. Available on Hulu.

• “The Gray Man” (PG-13): CIA operative Court Gentry (Ryan Gosling), aka, Sierra Six, is removed from a federal penitentiary and recruited by Donald Fitzroy (Billy Bob Thornton). Once an agency-sanctioned merchant of death, Gentry becomes the target, hunted across the globe by Lloyd Hansen (Chris Evans), a former cohort at the CIA. Available on Netflix.

• “Persuasion” (PG): Set in the early 1800s, Anne Elliot (Dakota Johnson), an unconforming young woman, lives with her snobby family. When Frederick Wentworth (Cosmo Jarvis), the dashing one she let get away, comes back into her life, Anne must choose between putting the past behind her or listening to her heart. Adapted from the Jane Austen novel. Also starring Henry Golding and Mia McKenna-Bruce. Available on Netflix.

• “The Sea Beast” (PG): Computer-animated adventure film of an era where terrifying beasts roamed the seas and monster hunters were celebrated heroes, including Jacob Holland. When young Maisie Brumble stows away on his fabled ship, they embark on an epic journey into uncharted waters. From Academy Award winning filmmaker Chris Williams (Moana, Big Hero 6, Bolt). Starring Karl Urban, Zaris-Angel Hator, Jared Harris and Marianne Jean-Baptiste. Available on Netflix.

• “Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness” (PG-13): New film with Marvel Studios’ comic book superhero Doctor Strange, who with the help of mystical allies, traverses alternate realities of the Multiverse to confront a new adversary. Starring Benedict Cumberbatch, Elizabeth Olsen, Benedict Wong and Patrick Stewart.

• “Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore” (PG-13): The newest adventure in the Wizarding World franchise centered on Harry Potter novels by J.K. Rowling. Professor Albus Dumbledore (Jude Law) gathers a team to stop dark wizard Gellert Grindelwald (Mads Mikkelsen) from seizing control of the wizarding world. Also starring Eddie Redmayne, Dan Fogler, Alison Sudol and Ezra Miller.

• “The Bob’s Burgers Movie” (PG-13): Animated, musical comedy-mystery-adventure based on the long-running series. The story begins when a ruptured water main creates a sinkhole in front of Bob’s Burgers, blocking the entrance indefinitely. Directed by Bernard Derriman.

• “Mr. Malcolm’s List” (PG): A period drama based on the novel of the same name about a woman’s revenge when jilted by London’s most eligible bachelor. Starring Freida Pinto, Sope Dirisu, Oliver Jackson-Cohen, Ashley Park, Zawe Ashton and Theo James.

• “Black Bird”: A six-episode psychological thriller inspired by actual events. When high school football hero, decorated policeman’s son and convicted drug dealer Jimmy Keene (Taron Egerton) is sentenced to 10 years in a minimum security prison, he is given the choice to enter a maximum-security prison for the criminally insane and befriend suspected serial killer Larry Hall (Paul Walter Hauser). Also starring Sepideh Moafi and Greg Kinnear. Available on Apple TV+.

• “Crimes of the Future” (R): Sci-fi drama centered on the human species adapting to a synthetic environment. Saul Tenser (Viggo Mortensen), a celebrity performance artist, with his partner Caprice (Léa Seydoux), publicly showcase the metamorphosis of his organs in avant-garde performances. Timlin (Kristen Stewart), an investigator from the National Organ Registry, tracks their movements, revealing a mysterious group.

• “Spiderhead” (R): In a state-of-the-art penitentiary run by Steve Abnesti (Chris Hemsworth), inmates wear a surgically attached device that administers dosages of mind-altering drugs. Also starring Miles Teller and Jurnee Smollett. Based on The New Yorker short story by George Saunders, the movie is a darkly funny psychological thriller directed by Joseph Kosinski. Available on Netflix.

• “Brian and Charles” (PG): Brian, a lonely inventor in rural Wales, uses a washing machine and various spare parts to invent Charles, an artificially intelligent robot. Starring David Earl, Chris Hayward and Louise Brealey.

• “Sonic-The Hedgehog 2”: Sonic (voiced by Ben Schwartz), is eager to prove he has what it takes to be a true hero in this sequel. His test comes when Dr. Robotnik returns, this time with a new partner, Knuckles, in search for an emerald that has the power to destroy civilizations. Also starring James Marsden, Tika Sumpter, and Natasha Rothwell.

• “The Bad Guys” (PG): Computer-animated action comedy from DreamWorks Animation, based on the book series of the same name, a crackerjack criminal crew of animal outlaws pose as model citizens in order to avoid prison. Starring Sam Rockwell, Craig Robinson and Anthony Ramos.

• “Downton Abbey-A New Era” (PG): From award-winning creator Julian Fellowes comes a new Downton Abbey film with the cast traveling to the South of France to uncover the mystery of the Dowager Countess’ newly inherited villa. Starring Hugh Bonneville, Laura Carmichael, Jim Carter, Raquel Cassidy and Michelle Dockery.

• “The Phantom of the Open” (PG-13): The film follows Maurice Flitcroft (Mark Rylance), a dreamer and unrelenting optimist who managed to gain entry to The British Open Golf Championship Qualifying in 1976. Also starring Sally Hawkins and Rhys Ifans.

• “Watcher” (R): As a serial killer stalks the city, a young actress who just moved to town with her boyfriend notices a mysterious stranger watching her from across the street. Starring Maika Monroe, Burn Gorman, Karl Glusman and Madalina Anea.

• “The Northman” (R): Robert Eggers directs this action-filled epic that follows a young Viking prince on his quest to avenge his father’s murder. Starring Alexander Skarsgård, Nicole Kidman and Claes Bang, Ethan Hawke, Björk and Willem Dafoe.

• “Everything Everywhere All at Once” (R): Comedic sci-fi action adventure about an exhausted Chinese American woman (Michelle Yeoh) who can’t seem to finish her taxes. Also starring Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, Jenny Slate, Harry Shum Jr., with James Hong and Jamie Lee Curtis.

• “Good Luck to You, Leo Grande” (R): Emma Thompson stars as a retired teacher Nancy Stokes, and newcomer Daryl McCormack (Peaky Blinders) personifies the charisma and compassion of sex worker Leo Grande. Available on Hulu.

• “Cha Cha Real Smooth” (R): Fresh out of college and without a clear life path going forward, 22-year-old Andrew is stuck back at home with his family in New Jersey. He lands a job of motivational dancing at the bar and bat mitzvahs for his younger brother’s classmates, and befriends a local mom, Domino, and her daughter, Lola. Cooper Raiff writes, directs and stars alongside Dakota Johnson, Brad Garrett, Leslie Mann. Available on Apple TV+.

• “Fire Island” (R): Andrew Ahn’s modern day rom-com showcasing a diverse, multicultural examination of queerness and romance. Inspired by the timeless pursuits from Jane Austen’s classic “Pride and Prejudice”, the story centers around a group of friends who gather at Fire Island of New York for their annual summer of love and laughter. Starring Joel Kim Booster, Bowen Yang, Margaret Cho, Conrad Ricamora and James Scully. Available on Hulu.

• “Ms. Marvel”: Marvel Studios’ “Ms. Marvel” is a new, original series that introduces Kamala Khan, a Muslim American teenager growing up in Jersey City. Kamala is an avid gamer, fan-fiction scribe and a Super Hero mega fan, especially Captain Marvel. Starring Iman Vellani as Kamala Khan aka Ms. Marvel, Aramis Knight, Saagar Shaikh and Rish Shah. Available on Disney+.

• “Firestarter” (R): New adaptation of Stephen King’s classic thriller, a girl with extraordinary pyrokinetic powers fights to protect her family and herself from sinister forces that seek to capture her and use her powers for a weapon of mass destruction. Starring Zac Efron, Ryan Kiera Armstrong, Sydney Lemmon, Kurtwood Smith and John Beasley. Available
